title: Business Tax Account | Internal Revenue Service
summary: The IRS provides a Business Tax Account service that allows small business owners to make payments, view records, receive notices and more.
key_requirements: Business owners need to sign in to the Business Tax Account to access the services.
recommended_actions: Small business owners should sign in to their Business Tax Account to manage their tax obligations, view records, and receive important notices.

title: Business taxes | Internal Revenue Service
summary: The page provides information about the types of federal business taxes that small businesses need to be aware of. These include income tax, estimated tax, self-employment tax, employment taxes, and excise tax.
key_requirements: Income tax: Businesses must file an annual income tax return.
Estimated tax: Businesses that expect to owe tax of $1,000 or more when their return is filed, must make estimated tax payments.
Self-employment tax: This is a Social Security and Medicare tax primarily for individuals who work for themselves.
Employment taxes: Businesses with employees have certain employment tax responsibilities.

Excise tax: Businesses may be required to pay this if they manufacture or sell certain products, operate certain kinds of businesses, use various kinds of equipment, facilities, or products, or receive payment for certain services.
important_deadlines: Annual income tax return deadline
Quarterly estimated tax payment deadlines
recommended_actions: Ensure your business is compliant with all relevant federal tax obligations.
Make note of and meet all tax filing and payment deadlines.
Consider consulting with a tax professional to ensure you are meeting all your tax obligations.

title: Get a business tax transcript | Internal Revenue Service
summary: The page provides information on how to obtain a business tax transcript online through your business tax account or by mail using Form 4506-T. It also details what a transcript shows, when you can request a business transcript, the types of business transcripts, and what to do if your transcript is incorrect.
key_requirements: Business tax transcripts can be requested online or by mail
Form 4506-T is required for mail requests
recommended_actions: Check your business tax account for online access to your tax transcript
If online access is not available, prepare to mail Form 4506-T to request a transcript
Review the transcript for accuracy once received

title: Small Businesses Self-Employed | Internal Revenue Service
summary: The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) provides a variety of resources for small businesses and self-employed individuals. These include tax forms such as Form Schedule C and Form 941, publications, eLearning resources, and more. This information is particularly relevant for small businesses with assets under $10 million.
key_requirements: Small businesses must file appropriate tax forms, including Form Schedule C for profit or loss from business and Form 941 for employer's quarterly federal tax return.
Small businesses should stay updated with IRS publications and eLearning resources to ensure tax compliance.
important_deadlines: Form 941 is typically due by the last day of the month following the end of the quarter.
Form Schedule C is usually due by April 15 of the year following the tax year.
recommended_actions: Visit the IRS website regularly to access necessary tax forms and stay updated with the latest information.
Consider using eLearning resources provided by the IRS to better understand tax obligations.
File necessary tax forms such as Form Schedule C and Form 941 in a timely manner to avoid penalties.

Electronic deposit is required.

Knowing how to calculate estimated tax
Being aware of when to pay estimated taxes
Understanding the penalties for underpayment of estimated tax
important_deadlines: Estimated taxes are typically due in four equal installments throughout the year: April 15, June 15, September 15, and January 15 of the following year.
recommended_actions: Determine if your business is required to pay estimated taxes.
Learn how to calculate your estimated tax payments.
Ensure you pay your estimated taxes on time to avoid penalties.

Businesses must obtain an Employer Identification Number.

title: Filing past due tax returns | Internal Revenue Service
summary: This page provides information on how to file past due tax returns. It emphasizes the importance of filing past due returns to avoid interest and penalties, claim a refund, protect social security benefits, and avoid issues obtaining loans. It also outlines the consequences of not filing voluntarily, including substitute returns and collection and enforcement actions.
key_requirements: File past due tax returns as soon as possible to avoid penalties and interest.
If you owe more than you can pay, consider payment options such as installment agreements and offers in compromise.
If you don't file voluntarily, the IRS may file a substitute return, which may not give you credit for deductions and exemptions you may be entitled to.
important_deadlines: There are no specific deadlines mentioned for filing past due returns, but it should be done as soon as possible to minimize penalties and interest.
recommended_actions: File any past due tax returns as soon as possible.
If you owe more than you can pay, explore payment options with the IRS.
Seek help if you're having trouble filing your past due return.

title: Get an employer identification number | Internal Revenue Service
summary: The page provides information on how small businesses can obtain an Employer Identification Number (EIN) directly from the IRS. An EIN is necessary for tax filing and reporting purposes.
key_requirements: Businesses must apply for an EIN if they meet certain criteria such as having employees, operating as a corporation or partnership, or filing tax returns for employment, excise, or Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms.
Businesses can apply for an EIN online, by fax, mail, or, for international applicants, by phone.
important_deadlines: There are no specific deadlines mentioned for obtaining an EIN, but it is recommended to get one as soon as the business meets the criteria.
recommended_actions: Check if your business meets the criteria for needing an EIN.
Apply for an EIN using the preferred method (online, fax, mail, or phone for international applicants).
Keep the EIN in a safe place for future reference and use in tax filing and reporting.

title: elaws - FLSA Overtime Calculator Advisor for Nonexempt Employees
summary: The U.S. Department of Labor provides an FLSA Overtime Calculator Advisor for Nonexempt Employees. This tool helps employers and employees understand Federal overtime requirements. A final rule announced on April 23, 2024, will take effect on July 1, 2024, updating and revising the regulations for exemptions from minimum wage and overtime pay requirements for certain employees.
key_requirements: Covered, nonexempt employees must be paid at least the Federal minimum wage for all hours worked.
Nonexempt employees must receive overtime pay at one and one-half times the regular rate of pay for all hours worked after 40 hours in a workweek.
The regular rate is calculated by dividing the total pay for employment (except for statutory exclusions) in any workweek by the total number of hours actually worked.
important_deadlines: The final rule updating and revising the regulations for exemptions from minimum wage and overtime pay requirements will take effect on July 1, 2024.
recommended_actions: Use the FLSA Overtime Calculator Advisor to understand Federal overtime requirements.
Prepare for the implementation of the final rule on July 1, 2024, which includes increases to the standard salary level and the highly compensated employee total annual compensation threshold.

title: elaws - FLSA Overtime Security Advisor
summary: The U.S. Department of Labor has announced a final rule, effective from July 1, 2024, which updates and revises the regulations under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) regarding the exemption from minimum wage and overtime pay requirements for certain employees. The FLSA Overtime Security Advisor provides information to help employers and employees understand these federal overtime security requirements.
key_requirements: Understanding the exemptions from minimum wage and overtime pay requirements for executive, administrative, and professional (EAP) employees.
Being aware of the increases to the standard salary level and the highly compensated employee total annual compensation threshold.
Understanding the mechanism that provides for the timely and efficient updating of these earnings thresholds to reflect current earnings data.
important_deadlines: The final rule takes effect on July 1, 2024.
recommended_actions: Review the final rule and understand its implications for your business.
Identify any employees who fall under the EAP exemptions.
Adjust payroll systems to accommodate the increases to the standard salary level and highly compensated employee total annual compensation threshold.
Monitor updates to the earnings thresholds.

title: elaws - Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Child Labor Rules Advisor
summary: The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Child Labor Rules Advisor provides guidance on Federal child labor rules. The Act establishes minimum wage, overtime pay, recordkeeping, and child labor rules affecting full- and part-time workers in the private sector and in the Federal, state and local governments. The rules vary depending on the age of the young worker and their occupation.
key_requirements: All states have child labor standards. When Federal and state standards are different, the rules that provide the most protection to young workers will apply.
Once an employee is 18, there are no Federal child labor rules.
Federal child labor rules do not require work permits. However, many states issue age certificates if you are asked to provide them by your employer.
recommended_actions: Ensure compliance with both federal and state child labor laws, especially if they differ. The rules that provide the most protection to young workers will apply.
Understand that there are no federal child labor rules for employees aged 18 and above.
Be aware that while federal rules do not require work permits, many states issue age certificates if asked by employers.

title: elaws - FLSA Hours Worked Advisor
summary: The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Hours Worked Advisor provides information on Federal requirements for all covered, nonexempt employees to be paid at least the minimum wage for all hours worked. It emphasizes the importance of accurately determining the total number of hours worked by an employee in each workweek for correct pay calculation.
key_requirements: All covered, nonexempt employees must be paid at least the minimum wage for all hours worked.
A workweek, which can begin on any day of the week, is seven consecutive 24-hour periods or 168 consecutive hours.
An employee must be paid for all of the time considered to be hours worked.
All time that is hours worked must be counted when determining overtime hours worked.
recommended_actions: Review the coverage or exemptions under the FLSA.
Ensure accurate tracking of the total number of hours actually worked by each employee in each workweek.
Ensure all employees are paid at least the minimum wage for all hours worked.
Count all time that is considered hours worked when determining overtime hours worked.

title: Application of the Fair Labor Standards Act to Direct Care Workers
summary: The page discusses the application of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) to direct care workers. It mentions a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking addressing the FLSA’s exemption of employees who provide companionship services and live-in domestic service employees.

title: Fact Sheet #21: Recordkeeping Requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)
summary: This page provides information on the recordkeeping requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). It outlines the types of records that employers must maintain, including employee personal information, hours worked, wages earned, and more.
key_requirements: Employers must maintain accurate records of employees' personal information, including full name, social security number, address, birth date (if under 19), gender, and occupation.
Employers must keep track of hours worked each day and total hours worked each week.
Records of wages paid, including regular hourly rates, overtime earnings, and total wages paid each pay period, must be kept.
Employers must maintain records of any additions to or deductions from wages.
Employers must keep records of the dates, amounts, and nature of the items that make up the total additions and deductions.
important_deadlines: Records must be kept for at least three years for payroll records, collective bargaining agreements, sales and purchase records.

Records on which wage computations are based should be retained for two years, such as time cards and piece work tickets, wage rate tables, work and time schedules, and records of additions to or deductions from wages.
recommended_actions: Ensure that your business is keeping accurate and comprehensive records of all required information.
Retain these records for the required amount of time.
Consider implementing a reliable system or software to aid in recordkeeping.

Check that your practices align with the regulations about sleeping time and certain other activities

title: Overtime Pay | U.S. Department of Labor
summary: This page from the U.S. Department of Labor provides information and resources about federal overtime laws and regulations. It includes guidance, fact sheets, and other resources to help employers understand their obligations under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) regarding overtime pay.
key_requirements: Employers must pay employees overtime pay for hours worked over 40 in a workweek at a rate not less than time and one-half their regular rates of pay.
Overtime pay is not required for work on weekends, holidays, or regular days of rest, unless overtime hours are worked on such days.
The Act applies on a workweek basis, and each workweek stands alone.
recommended_actions: Review the overtime guidance and fact sheets provided on the page to understand your obligations under the FLSA.
Ensure your payroll system is set up to correctly calculate and pay overtime to eligible employees.
